definition:
A metric space $X$ is said to be a *real tree* or *${\mathbb}{R}$-tree*,
if for each $x,y\in X$ there is a unique arc from $x$ to $y$, and
furthermore this arc is an isometric .

Every real tree is a hyperbolic metric space; moreover, every real tree
is 0 hyperbolic.

The Cayley graph of any free group is considered to be a real tree. Note
that its graph is a tree in the graph theoretic sense. To make it a real
tree, we view the edges as to the line segment $[0,1]$ under a
(surjective) and attach the edges to the tree. The resulting 1-complex
is then a locally finite real tree. Because of this result, every free
group is a hyperbolic group.
